docs.snippet: DURDIN-Margaret (Peggy). Age 92, of pneumonia on February 12, 2002, at Silverado Senior Living, Encinitas, California. Beloved wife of the late F. Tillman Durdin, loving sister of Maude Hudson and Lena Albright, both deceased, and of brother Oscar...
docs.lead_paragraph: DURDIN-Margaret (Peggy). Age 92, of pneumonia on February 12, 2002, at Silverado Senior Living, Encinitas, California. Beloved wife of the late F. Tillman Durdin, loving sister of Maude Hudson and Lena Albright, both deceased, and of brother Oscar V. Armstrong of Mitchellville, MD, & of informally ``adopted'' son Edward Chen of Hong Kong. Born in China of missionary parents, she spent many years in Asia, accompanying her husband, a New York Times correspondent and writing feature articles for various American publications. She also served as an assistant to the editor of the New York Times Magazine.

docs.snippet: ''Leashed and unleashed'' might sum up the difference between the two big art fairs gracing New York this weekend.     At the Armory Show, anything goes. Big, noisy and extremely hip, it will make traditionalists gnash their teeth. But at the Art ...
docs.lead_paragraph: ''Leashed and unleashed'' might sum up the difference between the two big art fairs gracing New York this weekend. At the Armory Show, anything goes. Big, noisy and extremely hip, it will make traditionalists gnash their teeth. But at the Art Show, at the Seventh Regiment Armory, things are calm, quiet and tony. Displays by 70 dealers include 17th- and 18th-century artists like Rembrandt and Goya, and some contemporary artists like Jonathan Lasker. But the bulk of the show consists of paintings, sculptures and works on paper by textbook-certified Modernists and their acolytes, from Vuillard to Picasso and Pollock to Warhol. Here, once insouciant Pop-style rebels like Roy Lichtenstein and Jim Dine look like classicists.
docs.abstract: Ken Johnson reviews the Art Show at Seventh Regiment Armory in Manhattan; photos (M)

headline.main: For Those in Search of Calm, an Armory Full of Modernists

docs.snippet: Peggy Durdin, a foreign correspondent and writer who in the course of four decades covered almost every country in Asia, died on Feb. 12 in Encinitas, Calif. She was 92.     Ms. Durdin, who began writing in 1938 after marrying Tillman Durdin, a lo...
docs.lead_paragraph: Peggy Durdin, a foreign correspondent and writer who in the course of four decades covered almost every country in Asia, died on Feb. 12 in Encinitas, Calif. She was 92. Ms. Durdin, who began writing in 1938 after marrying Tillman Durdin, a longtime foreign correspondent for The New York Times, almost immediately delved into areas that at the time were rarely covered by women.
docs.abstract: Peggy Durdin, foreign correspondent and writer who in course of four decades covered almost every country in Asia, dies at 92; she began writing in 1938 after marrying Tillman Durdin, longtime foreign correspondent for New York Times; photo (M)

headline.main: Peggy Durdin, 92, Reporter on Asia, Dies

docs.snippet: 'Color Purple' Set to Music      Showing once again that almost any work of literature is really just potential fodder for show tunes, producers have announced that they are developing ''The Color Purple,'' Alice Walker's award-winning novel of ra...
docs.lead_paragraph: 'Color Purple' Set to Music Showing once again that almost any work of literature is really just potential fodder for show tunes, producers have announced that they are developing ''The Color Purple,'' Alice Walker's award-winning novel of race and redemption, into a full-scale musical.
docs.abstract: New company called Creative Battery, founded by Scott Sanders, is developing Alice Walker's award-winning novel, The Color Purple, as musical, to be directed by Matthew Warchus, adapted by actress and playwright Regina Taylor with songs by Brenda Russell, Allee Willis and Stephen Bray; audience member suffers fatal heart attack during performance of The Producers; Elaine Stritch, who is diabetic, speaks first word of her show, Elaine Stritch At Liberty, then delays show for 30 minutes before returning to stage; British producer Robert Fox, who has signed several deals in recent weeks, signs Dames Judi Dench and Maggie Smith for David Hare play The Breath of Life, which will open in London in fall; play Metamorphoses, which has begun previews on Broadway, started out as 1996 student production at Northwestern University; Erik Lochtefeld, Chris Kipiniak and Louise Lamson are still with show; photo (On Stage and Off column) (M)

docs.snippet: IN this fabulous Olympic hockey tournament, there have been six or seven countries that swore, absolutely swore, they invented this sport, or at least purchased it, in the case of the United States.    However, we worry for Canada. We worry a lot....
docs.lead_paragraph: IN this fabulous Olympic hockey tournament, there have been six or seven countries that swore, absolutely swore, they invented this sport, or at least purchased it, in the case of the United States. However, we worry for Canada. We worry a lot. Having expended so much national angst on Jamie Salé and David Pelletier, Canada then had to fight off the lurking suspicion that its figure skating officials were way over the top in lobbying for their skaters. Their women lost in curling to Britain yesterday. Britain! Now the nation must store up its psychic strength for hockey.
docs.abstract: George Vecsey Sports of The Times column submits humorous list of things to love about Canada even if Belarus manages another upset and Canada fails to win gold medal in Olympic hockey tournament (M)

headline.main: Sports of The Times; Now Canada Must Duck The Upset

docs.snippet: A Roman Catholic priest sought in California as a fugitive from justice on child molestation charges was arraigned in Superior Court in Hartford yesterday after being arrested on Saturday at a Hartford behavioral treatment center. The 35-year-old ...
docs.lead_paragraph: A Roman Catholic priest sought in California as a fugitive from justice on child molestation charges was arraigned in Superior Court in Hartford yesterday after being arrested on Saturday at a Hartford behavioral treatment center. The 35-year-old priest, whose name is reported as Oskar Pelaez by the Hartford police and as Oscar Alberto Pelaez by the police in California, served at Sacred Heart Church in Turlock, Calif. He was charged with being a fugitive from justice and held in $500,000 bail. He agreed to be extradited to California. Tara Bahrampour (NYT)
docs.abstract: Roman Catholic priest Oskar Pelaez is arraigned in Hartford on child molestation charges; he has agreed to be extradited to California, where he is charged with being fugitive from justice (S)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Hartford: Fugitive Priest Arraigned

byline.original: By Tara Bahrampour (NYT) (Compiled by Anthony Ramirez)

docs.snippet: Sumptuous  The dagger has a handle of gold and a sheath adorned with more than 2,400 rubies, emeralds and diamonds. The finger ring is a bit unusual; it is decorated with a rotating, bobbing bird made of gold and set with rubies, emeralds, chrysob...
docs.lead_paragraph: Sumptuous The dagger has a handle of gold and a sheath adorned with more than 2,400 rubies, emeralds and diamonds. The finger ring is a bit unusual; it is decorated with a rotating, bobbing bird made of gold and set with rubies, emeralds, chrysoberyl cat's eyes, diamond and one sapphire. Not to be overlooked is the ruby-colored gemstone inscribed with the names of six owners, all royal. These are among approximately 325 objects, many also lavished with gems set in pure gold that go on view on Sunday at the Cleveland Museum of Art. The exhibition, ''Treasury of the World: Jeweled Arts of India in the Age of the Mughals,'' harks back to 17th-century India. Organized by the al-Sabah Collection of the Kuwait National Museum, the display continues through May 19. For Eye and Ear The circus that comes to town at 8 tonight is definitely not your ordinary circus. Don't look for a big top or three rings. The performance takes place on the stage of City Center in Manhattan, and the attraction is Cirque Éloize from Montreal. Cirque Éloize belongs to the category of circuses called nouveau, but that's not all, because the show it is bringing to town for six performances through Sunday is ''Cirque Orchestra.'' Sharing the stage in this presentation of Lincoln Center's Great Performers New Visions series will be the Orchestra of St. Luke's, conducted by Miguel Harth-Bedoya. So, while performers like acrobats and trapeze artists engage in balletic feats and other gravity-defying flights of fancy, the orchestra will be playing the music of Tchaikovsky, Sibelius, Fauré, Rimsky-Korsakov, Saint-Saëns and Moussorgsky. The Cirque Éloize troupe includes three dancing actors and 13 multidisciplinary performers.
docs.abstract: Jeweled artworks dating to 17th-century India will go on view at Cleveland Museum of Art; photo (S)

docs.snippet: Her majesty is a royal train wreck. Oh, sure, she's kind of pretty in her pasty, anemic way. But she is as weak as she is pale.    Why, she can't dress herself, or feed herself, or even go to the bathroom without elaborate help. And she is no good...
docs.lead_paragraph: Her majesty is a royal train wreck. Oh, sure, she's kind of pretty in her pasty, anemic way. But she is as weak as she is pale. Why, she can't dress herself, or feed herself, or even go to the bathroom without elaborate help. And she is no good at all at the games she has to play: politics, love, badminton (yes, badminton). This babe may be highborn, but she is also born to lose.
docs.abstract: Ben Brantley reviews Wooster Group production of play To You, The Birdie! (Phedre), based on Paul Schmidt's translation of Racine's Phedre, directed by Elizabeth Le Compte; Frances McDormand, Kate Valk and Willem Dafoe star; photos (M)

headline.main: Racine's Pale Queen, Struggling With Racket Sports

docs.snippet: Enough about who may have pressured the French judge Marie Reine Le Gougne to tilt her pairs skating vote to the Russians. The real question in the minds of Olympic fans is, ''What's going on with those ice dancing clothes?''    In an attempt to c...
docs.lead_paragraph: Enough about who may have pressured the French judge Marie Reine Le Gougne to tilt her pairs skating vote to the Russians. The real question in the minds of Olympic fans is, ''What's going on with those ice dancing clothes?'' In an attempt to comprehend the symbolism behind one skater's choice of costume, a writer for The New Yorker once concluded that Michelle Kwan's subliminal message was, ''I am going to make my first Communion, and I intend to yodel.'' Ms. Kwan, who has often worn Vera Wang costumes in performance, is practically Brooke Astor compared with the current crop of skaters, whose get-ups often seem to have been unearthed from the wardrobe trunk of a Bulgarian circus or found on the set of ''The Lawrence Welk Show.''
docs.abstract: Comment on fashions worn by Olympic figure skaters in their skating routines; photo (S)9

headline.main: Front Row; For better or worse, Olympic ice skaters have escaped the fashion police An unpublicized designer makes an art out of sewing.

docs.snippet: KRIEGMAN-Oscar M. Of Wayne, New Jersey on Sunday, February 17, 2002. Beloved husband of Ada (nee Kesden); devoted father of David & Mrs. Michelle King; loving grandfather of Bryce & Dylan Kriegman and Alexander King; dear brother of Leslie and the...
docs.lead_paragraph: KRIEGMAN-Oscar M. Of Wayne, New Jersey on Sunday, February 17, 2002. Beloved husband of Ada (nee Kesden); devoted father of David & Mrs. Michelle King; loving grandfather of Bryce & Dylan Kriegman and Alexander King; dear brother of Leslie and the late Stanley & Bertram. Funeral from the Bernheim-Apter-Kreitzman Suburban Funeral Chapel, 68 Old Short Hills Road, Livingston, NJ, Tuesday, Feb. 19, at 1 P.M. Interment Beth Israel Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Jewish Family and Children's Service of North Jersey, 1 Pike Drive, Wayne, N.J. 07470.

headline.main: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRIEGMAN, OSCAR M.
